description: From Middle English hoste, from Old French oste (French: hôte), from Latin hospitem, accusative of hospes (“a host, also a sojourner, visitor, guest; hence, a foreigner, a stranger”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰostipotis (“master of guests”), from *gʰóstis (“stranger, guest, enemy”) and *pótis (“owner, master, host, husband”). Used in English since 13th century. Doublet of guest.

entries.meaning: One which receives or entertains a guest, socially, commercially, or officially.
examples: A good host is always considerate of the guest’s needs.

entries.meaning: One that provides a facility for an event.
A person or organization responsible for running an event.
examples: Our company is host of the annual conference this year.

entries.meaning: A moderator or master of ceremonies for a performance.
examples: The host was terrible, but the acts themselves were good.

entries.meaning: (computing, Internet) Any computer attached to a network.
(ecology) A cell or organism which harbors another organism or biological entity, usually a parasite.
examples: Viruses depend on the host that they infect in order to be able to reproduce.

entries.meaning: (evolution, genetics) An organism bearing certain genetic material, with respect to its cells.
examples: The so-called junk DNA is known, so far, to provide no apparent benefit to its host.

entries.meaning: A paid male companion offering conversation and in some cases sex, as in certain types of bar in Japan.

verbs.description: host (third-person singular simple present hosts, present participle hosting, simple past and past participle hosted)

entries.meaning: To perform the role of a host.
examples: Our company will host the annual conference this year.
I was terrible at hosting that show.
I’ll be hosting tonight. I hope I’m not terrible.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To lodge at an inn.
(computing, Internet) To run software made available to a remote user or process.
examples: CMU/TEK TCP/IP software uses an excessive amount of cpu resources for terminal support both outbound, when accessing another system, and inbound, when the local system is hosting a session.

description: From Middle English oost, borrowed from Old French ost, oste, hoste, from Latin hostis (“foreign enemy”) (as opposed to inimicus (“personal enemy”)); cognate with etymology 1 through an Indo-European root.

entries.meaning: A multitude of people arrayed as an army; used also in religious senses, as: Heavenly host (of angels)
examples: the invading host that had sailed from Hellas in more than one thousand ships was of an unprecedented size.

entries.meaning: A large number of items; a large inventory.
examples: The dealer stocks a host of parts for my Model A.

description: From Middle English host, oist, ost, from Old French hoiste, from Latin hostia (“sacrificial victim”). Doublet of hostie.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) The consecrated bread of the Eucharist.
